titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lower East Side Oral History Project OH.033
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Unattributed Tamiment staff, David Olson, and Heather Mulliner

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-12-11T11:47-0500

change.item: Finding aid notes written by David Olson, adapting content from MARC record by unattributed NYU staff and consulting with Rachel Bernstein. Inventory of interviews compiled by Heather Mulliner.

did.unittitle: Lower East Side Oral History Project

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 1 record carton and 10 card catalog drawers

did.abstract: The Lower East Side Oral History Project was undertaken between 1991-1995 to document immigrant life and work on New York City's Lower East Side. Rachel Bernstein, with the New York University Program in Public History, organized collaborations with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Henry Street Settlement House, and the Workmen's Circle to collect interviews. Topics covered by the interviews include growing up in tenements, family life, ethnic identities, religion, paid and unpaid work, small businesses, union activity, and political activism. Interviews were conducted by NYU graduate students in Bernstein's Oral History and Public History classes. Interviews are generally accompanied by indices and the interviewer's session notes. Many have been transcribed, as well.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Lower East Side Oral History Project was undertaken between 1991-1995 to document immigrant life and work on New York City's Lower East Side. Rachel Bernstein, with the New York University Program in Public History, organized collaborations with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Henry Street Settlement House, and the Workmen's Circle to collect interviews.

Most of the interviews were conducted by NYU graduate students in Bernstein's Oral History and Public History classes. Additional interviews were done by volunteers from the Workmen's Circle, trained by Bernstein in two daylong seminars organized as part of a collaboration between Workmen's Circle and the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains interviews with immigrants and children of immigrants who lived on the Lower East Side, the majority of them from Eastern European Jewish backgrounds. Topics covered by the interviews include growing up in tenements, family life, ethnic identities, religion, paid and unpaid work, small businesses, union activity, and political activism. Interviews are generally accompanied by indices and the interviewer's session notes. Many have been transcribed, as well.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of the original audio media, master cassettes must be digitized before access by researchers. To request digitization of materials, please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The first group of tapes were donated to the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives by Rachel Bernstein in 1993. Additional tapes were deposited with the library as subsequent phases of the project were completed.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Depending on the interview, copyright is held by the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives or the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives.

Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Content of majority of interviews is open for research without restrictions. Contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu for more information.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Many of the interviews represented here can also be found in Series 8 of the Henry Street Settlement records (sw0058) at the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives and at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Henry Street Settlement records (sw0058) at the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives also contains interviews from this project. While there is significant overlap between the interviews held by each repository, both hold unique interviews, as well.
Rachel Bernstein was a professor in the Public History program at New York University. The records of this program are housed at the New York University Archives (RG 20.9).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Interviews are arranged alphabetically by narrator's last name in finding aid.
The master cassettes were numbered as each batch was donated to the library. As such, these materials have a roughly chronological arrangement.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Repository received tapes after each phase of the project, and numbers were applied to these tapes. In 2013, a full finding aid was created, in which names were arranged by last name of narrator. As of 2013, some patron-driven digitization of master cassettes has occurred, but the majority of the collection remains untransferred.
